question.title: Circle approximations using Bezier curves
question.body:
I have 2 questions about bezier curves, and using them to approximate portions of circles.

  1. Given the unit circle arc (1,0)->(cos(a),sin(a)) where 0 < a < pi/2, will it result in a good approximation of this arc to find the bezier curve's control points p1, p2 by solving the equations imposed by the requirements B(1/3) = (cos(a/3), sin(a/3)) and B(2/3) = (cos(2a/3), sin(2a/3)). (In other words, requiring that the bezier curve go through two evenly spaced points in the arc).

  2. If we have an affine transformation A which turns the circle arc in an ellipse arc will the transformed control points Ap0, Ap1, Ap2, Ap3 define a good bezier approximation to the ellipse arc?

p0 and p3, of course, are the start and end points of the curve: (1,0) and (cos(a), sin(a)).

Thank you

answers.body:
Mike 'Pomax' Kamermans (above) has a page with a good approximation to a circle using Bezier curves at https://pomax.github.io/bezierinfo/#circles et seq, and Spenser Mortensen has an even more accurate approximation at https://spencermortensen.com/articles/bezier-circle/ (These approximations use 4 right circular arcs. Even better approximations can come from using more segments)

In https://pages.mtu.edu/~shene/COURSES/cs3621/NOTES/spline/Bezier/bezier-construct.html we find that applying a transform to a Bezier results in the same curve as applying the same transform to its control points.

In https://www.dropbox.com/s/su4bkjepexmwh1w/EllipseTransform.pdf?dl=0 Nathan Dinsmore shows how to apply a shear to a circle to transform it into an arbitrary ellipse specified by axes and rotation (with some code implementing his method at https://g6auc.me.uk/ellipses/index.html )

Put all the above together and you should be able to use the accurate approximation to a circle as your starting point, to whose control points you then apply the shears as above, resulting in the desired ellipse approximated by a piecewise Bezier curve with low error.

Here's a general solution for any elliptical arc as a cubic Bezier curve.

The error is most dependent on the difference of the start and end angles. I've had good success by limiting the angle difference to 60°. That is, I make a separate cubic segment for every 60° (or fraction thereof) and chain them together.
